docs.text:
CAD Learning Back What is CAD? Starting Place Start Lesson

A quick article that explains what CAD is, as well as how to set up an Onshape account using your Westtown email.

Onshape CAD Basics Beginner Start Lesson

A course designed by Onshape that's very useful for learning the fundamentals of general CAD.

CAD 3005 Beginner Start Lesson

An Onshape CAD class set up by 3005 The RoboChargers that walks through the basic skills needed to design an FRC robot. Great for those who prefer video-based learning.

FRCDesign.org Intermediate Start Lesson

A website that contains a helpful CAD learning course which is designed specifically around FRC parts and mechanisms.

docs.title: Onshape CAD Basics
docs.text:
Onshape CAD Basics

← Back to Lesson Overview

Introduction

Before starting this lesson, make sure that you have an Onshape account made with your westtown email address. To learn how to do this, you can visit here and scroll down to the "How to Setup an Onshape Account" section.

Once you have checked that you can log into that account, you're all good to go to proceed with this lesson!

The Onshape Course Access Resource

The Onshape design course is set up for individuals who wish to learn CAD from the very beginning, and introduces the basic functions of onshape as well as some best practices.

The course includes several "mini courses" which cover each section of CAD. After completing the entire course you will recieve a certificate of completion from Onshape.

It is recommended that you follow along with the course by opening an Onshape document in a seperate tab. To open a document, click the "create" button in the top left corner, and click "document".

Progress Tracker ♡
  • Introduction to Parametric Feature-Based CAD
  • Introduction to Sketching
  • Introduction to Part Studios
  • Introduction to Assembly Design
  • Introduction to Drawings
  • 10 Essential Onshape Tips
  • Onshape Hands-On Test Drive
Next Steps

Although this course has taught how to CAD generally, there are a lot of principles that are applied specifically in FRC that are important to learn. Make sure to keep practicing the basics of CAD to refresh your memory! In the Mini Projects section, you can find a few ideas on how to do this.

Finish Lesson

docs.title: RoboChargers CAD Class
docs.text:
CAD 3005

← Back to Lesson Overview

Introduction

The CAD 3005 course is created by FRC Team 3005 - The RoboChargers and is specifically designed to teach CAD skills that are directly applicable to FRC robotics. This course focuses on practical, hands-on learning through video tutorials and real FRC examples.

Getting Started Access Course

The course is structured as a YouTube playlist with multiple modules, each building on the previous lessons. You'll start with the basics of Onshape in an FRC context and work your way up to designing complete robot mechanisms.

Prerequisites: Make sure you have an Onshape account set up with your Westtown email address. If you need help with this, check out our What is CAD? lesson.

Course Modules

The course is divided into several modules that progressively build your FRC CAD skills:

  • Module 1: Onshape Basics for FRC
  • Module 2: Working with FRC Parts Libraries
  • Module 3: Drivetrain Design Fundamentals
  • Module 4: Mechanism Design Principles
  • Module 5: Assembly Techniques
  • Module 6: Robot Layout and Packaging
  • Module 7: Design for Manufacturing
  • Module 8: Advanced FRC Mechanisms
Learning Tips

To get the most out of this course:

  • Follow Along: Open Onshape in a separate tab and replicate what you see in the videos
  • Take Notes: Write down keyboard shortcuts and important design principles
  • Practice: Try to recreate mechanisms from memory after watching each lesson
Next Steps

After completing CAD 3005, you'll have the fundamental skills needed to contribute to FRC robot design. Consider exploring:

  • The FRCDesign.org course for more advanced techniques
  • Our Mini Projects section to practice your new skills

Finish Lesson

docs.title: What is CAD?
docs.text:
What is CAD?

← Back to Lesson Overview

Introduction

CAD stands for Computer-Aided Design, but don’t let that name scare you. If you’ve ever built with LEGO, drawn a robot on paper, or sketched an idea in your notebook, you’ve already done the thinking part of CAD.

CAD allows you to take these ideas and see them in a 3D space. Using CAD, you can see how parts interact with each other, and edit your geometry as needed before manufacturing anything. It's a tool thats used very often in the engineering world.

Commonly Used CAD Software

There are several CAD platforms that FRC teams commonly use. Each has its strengths depending on the team’s needs, school devices, or personal preference. Our preference at 1391 is Onshape due to the existing FRC part libraries, and collaboration features. Here are some popular CAD softwares:

  • Web based, acts like a Google Doc
  • Great for collaboration
  • Beginner friendly interface
  • Free for FRC teams & students
  • CAM Capabilities (Computer-Assisted Manufacturing)
  • Good for quick modeling
  • Free for students (education license)
  • Industry standard
  • Powerful but PC-only
  • Free licenses available through FIRST
Uses in FRC

In FRC, teams use CAD to plan their robots before building them. It saves time, avoids mistakes, and makes collaboration way easier. A crucial part of the build season is CADding the robot before machining it. Here’s an example using FRC 1678's 2025 robot.

How to Setup an Onshape Account
  1. Go to the Onshape Education page to get started.
  2. Scroll down and enter your first name, last name & westtown.edu email address. This is required to access the free education license.
  3. Verify your email by clicking the confirmation link sent to your Westtown inbox.
  4. Complete the onboarding steps— you might be asked about your role (student) and experience level.
  5. Once registered, you’ll have access to the full Onshape education platform and can start designing!
So I have an Onshape Account... What now?

CADding is just like riding a bike, or driving a car. It may seem intimidating at first, but with practice, it becomes easier. It's a crucial skill to learn for both FRC and Engineering. To help you in this journey, there are a variety of learning courses that you can find on this website. Happy making!

Finish Lesson

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Electrical What does this subteam do?
  • Organizes and installs wiring on beta and competition robots
  • Plans and mounts electrical components on the robot’s bellypan
  • Ensures all components are updated to latest firmware
  • Labels, tests, and troubleshoots the robot’s electrical systems
